core.persona: You are an expert literary analyst specializing in character relationships and narrative structure.

working.current_chapter_text:
CHAPTER XVII

After Anna Mikháylovna had driven off with her son to visit Count Cyril
Vladímirovich Bezúkhov, Countess Rostóva sat for a long time all
alone applying her handkerchief to her eyes. At last she rang.

“What is the matter with you, my dear?” she said crossly to the maid
who kept her waiting some minutes. “Don’t you wish to serve me? Then
I’ll find you another place.”

The countess was upset by her friend’s sorrow and humiliating poverty,
and was therefore out of sorts, a state of mind which with her always
found expression in calling her maid “my dear” and speaking to her
with exaggerated politeness.

“I am very sorry, ma’am,” answered the maid.

“Ask the count to come to me.”

The count came waddling in to see his wife with a rather guilty look as
usual.

“Well, little countess? What a sauté of game au madère we are to
have, my dear! I tasted it. The thousand rubles I paid for Tarás were
not ill-spent. He is worth it!”

He sat down by his wife, his elbows on his knees and his hands ruffling
his gray hair.

“What are your commands, little countess?”

“You see, my dear... What’s that mess?” she said, pointing to his
waistcoat. “It’s the sauté, most likely,” she added with a smile.
“Well, you see, Count, I want some money.”

Her face became sad.

“Oh, little countess!” ... and the count began bustling to get out
his pocketbook.

“I want a great deal, Count! I want five hundred rubles,” and taking
out her cambric handkerchief she began wiping her husband’s waistcoat.

“Yes, immediately, immediately! Hey, who’s there?” he called out
in a tone only used by persons who are certain that those they call will
rush to obey the summons. “Send Dmítri to me!”

Dmítri, a man of good family who had been brought up in the count’s
house and now managed all his affairs, stepped softly into the room.

“This is what I want, my dear fellow,” said the count to the
deferential young man who had entered. “Bring me...” he reflected
a moment, “yes, bring me seven hundred rubles, yes! But mind, don’t
bring me such tattered and dirty notes as last time, but nice clean ones
for the countess.”

“Yes, Dmítri, clean ones, please,” said the countess, sighing
deeply.

“When would you like them, your excellency?” asked Dmítri. “Allow
me to inform you... But, don’t be uneasy,” he added, noticing that
the count was beginning to breathe heavily and quickly which was always
a sign of approaching anger. “I was forgetting... Do you wish it
brought at once?”

“Yes, yes; just so! Bring it. Give it to the countess.”

“What a treasure that Dmítri is,” added the count with a smile when
the young man had departed. “There is never any ‘impossible’ with
him. That’s a thing I hate! Everything is possible.”

“Ah, money, Count, money! How much sorrow it causes in the world,”
said the countess. “But I am in great need of this sum.”

“You, my little countess, are a notorious spendthrift,” said the
count, and having kissed his wife’s hand he went back to his study.

When Anna Mikháylovna returned from Count Bezúkhov’s the money, all
in clean notes, was lying ready under a handkerchief on the countess’
little table, and Anna Mikháylovna noticed that something was agitating
her.

“Well, my dear?” asked the countess.

“Oh, what a terrible state he is in! One would not know him, he is so
ill! I was only there a few moments and hardly said a word...”

“Annette, for heaven’s sake don’t refuse me,” the countess
began, with a blush that looked very strange on her thin, dignified,
elderly face, and she took the money from under the handkerchief.

Anna Mikháylovna instantly guessed her intention and stooped to be
ready to embrace the countess at the appropriate moment.

“This is for Borís from me, for his outfit.”

Anna Mikháylovna was already embracing her and weeping. The countess
wept too. They wept because they were friends, and because they were
kindhearted, and because they—friends from childhood—had to think
about such a base thing as money, and because their youth was over....
But those tears were pleasant to them both.

workflow.goal: Analyze 'War and Peace' to extract characters, relationships, and significant events.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XIII
chapter_summaries.summary: In the conservatory of the Rostóv house, Natásha hides and observes a tender reconciliation between Nicholas and Sónya, who reaffirm their love with a kiss. After they leave, Natásha lures Borís to her hiding spot, where she impulsively kisses him and secures a promise that he will ask for her hand in marriage in four years when she is sixteen.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XIV
chapter_summaries.summary: Countess Rostóva and Princess Anna Mikháylovna have a private conversation about their financial struggles and social maneuvering. Meanwhile, the eldest daughter Véra interrupts the younger couples—Nicholas and Sónya, and Borís and Natásha—causing friction with her cold and critical demeanor. Anna Mikháylovna reveals how she used Prince Vasíli's influence to secure Borís's commission.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XV
chapter_summaries.summary: Princess Anna Mikháylovna and her son Borís visit the dying Count Cyril Bezúkhov in Moscow. While Borís feels humiliated by their poverty and his mother's sycophancy, Anna Mikháylovna persists in seeking favor from Prince Vasíli, who is managing the Count's affairs. They meet Prince Vasíli as he is dismissing the doctor, Lorrain, and Anna Mikháylovna attempts to secure her son's future by reminding the Prince of his obligations and the Count's role as Borís's godfather.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XVI
chapter_summaries.summary: Pierre Bezúkhov arrives in Moscow after being expelled from Petersburg for his scandalous behavior. He is coldly received by his cousins, the princesses, at his dying father's house. Prince Vasíli arrives and forbids Pierre from seeing the count. Later, Borís Drubetskóy visits Pierre to invite him to dinner at the Rostóvs', leading to a conversation where Pierre's social clumsiness and political obsessions are contrasted with Borís's cool, observant nature.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XVII
chapter_summaries.summary: Countess Rostóva, moved by Anna Mikháylovna's poverty, asks her husband for money. Despite their own financial decline, Count Rostóv provides seven hundred rubles. When Anna Mikháylovna returns from visiting the dying Count Bezúkhov, the Countess gives her the money for Borís's military outfit, leading to a tearful and affectionate exchange between the two lifelong friends.

42367a83-661b-44d3-9912-682f58053860.evolution_summary:
Illegitimate son of Count Bezúkhov; socially awkward and observant.
Introduced as a 'stout' and 'heavily built' young man whose naturalness and lack of artifice make him a disruptive force in the rigid salon environment.
His deep admiration for Prince Andrew is revealed, showing he has a loyal and emotional nature despite his social clumsiness.
Pierre transitions from being merely socially awkward to being a source of genuine political scandal in the salon by defending Napoleon's most controversial acts.
Pierre's physical clumsiness and social ineptitude are fully displayed, yet his essential 'kindly' nature earns him a reprieve from Anna Pávlovna.
Pierre's role as an 'outsider' is emphasized as he witnesses the private dysfunction of the Bolkónski marriage, showing his inability to handle emotional confrontation.
Pierre's vulnerability is highlighted as he admits his shame over his illegitimacy and his total reliance on Andrew's perceived 'strength of will'.
Pierre demonstrates a significant lack of character by immediately breaking a solemn promise to his mentor, Andrew. His physical strength is introduced as a 'Herculean' trait that contrasts with his mental indecision.
His reputation has plummeted following the events at Anatole's, making him a subject of ridicule and pity in Moscow.
Pierre has moved from a disruptive guest in Petersburg to a social pariah in Moscow, retreating into political fantasies (imagining himself as Napoleon) while being controlled by Prince Vasíli.

event_chronicle.description: Anna Pávlovna Schérer hosts a high-society reception in St. Petersburg.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: It was in July, 1805, and the speaker was the well-known Anna Pávlovna Schérer... greeting Prince Vasíli Kurágin, a man of high rank and importance, who was the first to arrive at her reception.

event_chronicle.description: Anna Pávlovna expresses her intense hatred for Napoleon and her faith in Emperor Alexander.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: if you still try to defend the infamies and horrors perpetrated by that Antichrist—I really believe he is Antichrist—I will have nothing more to do with you

event_chronicle.description: Pierre Bezúkhov arrives at the reception, causing social discomfort.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: Anna Pávlovna’s alarm was justified, for Pierre turned away from the aunt without waiting to hear her speech about Her Majesty’s health.

event_chronicle.description: Princess Bolkónskaya discusses her husband's departure for the war.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “You know,” said the princess... “my husband is deserting me? He is going to get himself killed. Tell me what this wretched war is for?”

event_chronicle.description: Anna Pávlovna gathers a group to hear the Vicomte de Mortemart's account of the Duc d’Enghien's death.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: Anna Pávlovna arranged a group round him, inviting everyone to listen to his tale.

event_chronicle.description: Prince Hippolyte Kurágin is introduced to the circle, displaying his lack of wit and awkward social presence.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: His face on the contrary was dulled by imbecility and a constant expression of sullen self-confidence

event_chronicle.description: Prince Andrew Bolkónski announces he is going to war as an aide-de-camp to General Kutúzov.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: General Kutúzov... has been pleased to take me as an aide-de-camp....

event_chronicle.description: Princess Drubetskáya successfully pressures Prince Vasíli into promising to help her son Borís.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: But in Princess Drubetskáya’s case he felt, after her second appeal, something like qualms of conscience.

event_chronicle.description: Pierre Bezúkhov publicly defends Napoleon's execution of the Duc d’Enghien as a political necessity.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “The execution of the Duc d’Enghien,” declared Monsieur Pierre, “was a political necessity, and it seems to me that Napoleon showed greatness of soul by not fearing to take on himself the whole responsibility of that deed.”

event_chronicle.description: Anna Pávlovna attempts to silence Pierre by inviting him to another table, which he ignores.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “Won’t you come over to the other table?” suggested Anna Pávlovna. But Pierre continued his speech without heeding her.

event_chronicle.description: Anna Pávlovna and Lise Bolkónskaya agree to pursue a marriage match between Anatole Kurágin and Andrew's sister.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “I rely on you, my dear,” said Anna Pávlovna, also in a low tone. “Write to her and let me know how her father looks at the matter.”

event_chronicle.description: Prince Andrew and Pierre leave the soiree together to continue their conversation at Andrew's home.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “I am expecting you, Pierre,” said the same voice, but gently and affectionately.

event_chronicle.description: Lise Bolkónskaya confronts Prince Andrew about his coldness and his decision to leave her for the war.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “Just for a whim of his own, goodness only knows why, he leaves me and locks me up alone in the country.”

event_chronicle.description: Lise reveals her pregnancy as a source of her fear, though she finds it 'indecorous' to speak of it directly before Pierre.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: She paused as if she felt it indecorous to speak of her pregnancy before Pierre, though the gist of the matter lay in that.

event_chronicle.description: Prince Andrew delivers a cynical monologue advising Pierre never to marry, citing the loss of nobility and freedom.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “Never, never marry, my dear fellow! That’s my advice: never marry till you can say to yourself that you have done all you are capable of”

event_chronicle.description: Pierre confesses his insecurity regarding his status as an illegitimate son without a name or means.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “What am I? An illegitimate son!” He suddenly blushed crimson, and it was plain that he had made a great effort to say this.

event_chronicle.description: Prince Andrew warns Pierre to stop associating with the Kurágins and their lifestyle of debauchery.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “But look here: give up visiting those Kurágins and leading that sort of life. It suits you so badly—all this debauchery, dissipation, and the rest of it!”

event_chronicle.description: Pierre breaks his promise to Prince Andrew by attending Anatole Kurágin's party.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: But he immediately recalled his promise to Prince Andrew not to go there. Then, as happens to people of weak character, he desired so passionately once more to enjoy that dissipation he was so accustomed to that he decided to go.

event_chronicle.description: Dólokhov bets Stevens that he can drink a bottle of rum while sitting on a third-story window ledge.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: Anatole kept on refilling Pierre’s glass while explaining that Dólokhov was betting with Stevens, an English naval officer, that he would drink a bottle of rum sitting on the outer ledge of the third floor window.

event_chronicle.description: Pierre uses his physical strength to wrench an oak window frame out of the wall.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: Pierre seized the crossbeam, tugged, and wrenched the oak frame out with a crash.

event_chronicle.description: Borís Drubetskóy is transferred to the Semënov Guards as a cornet through Prince Vasíli's influence.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: The matter was mentioned to the Emperor, an exception made, and Borís transferred into the regiment of Semënov Guards with the rank of cornet.

event_chronicle.description: The Rostóv family hosts a large name-day celebration in Moscow.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: It was St. Natalia’s day and the name day of two of the Rostóvs—the mother and the youngest daughter—both named Nataly.

event_chronicle.description: Moscow society gossips about Pierre Bezúkhov's expulsion from Petersburg and his father's illness.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: The conversation was on the chief topic of the day: the illness of the wealthy and celebrated beau of Catherine’s day, Count Bezúkhov, and about his illegitimate son Pierre

event_chronicle.description: The younger Rostóv children and their friends burst into the drawing room, disrupting the formal visit.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: suddenly from the next room were heard the footsteps of boys and girls running to the door and the noise of a chair falling over

event_chronicle.description: Borís Drubetskóy follows Natásha out of the room after she runs away in a fit of laughter.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: Borís quietly left the room and went in search of Natásha.

event_chronicle.description: Nicholas Rostóv publicly declares his vocation for the army, rejecting the idea that he is joining only for friendship with Borís.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “It’s not at all from friendship,” declared Nicholas, flaring up and turning away as if from a shameful aspersion. “It is not from friendship at all; I simply feel that the army is my vocation.”

event_chronicle.description: Sónya leaves the room in tears after witnessing Nicholas flirting with Julie Karágina.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: She gave him a passionately angry glance, and hardly able to restrain her tears and maintain the artificial smile on her lips, she got up and left the room.

event_chronicle.description: Nicholas and Sónya reconcile in the conservatory with a kiss, affirming their exclusive love for one another.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “Well, then, I won’t; only forgive me, Sónya!” He drew her to him and kissed her.

event_chronicle.description: Natásha and Borís agree to marry in four years after Natásha impulsively kisses him.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “Settled!” replied Borís. “Forever?” said the little girl. “Till death itself?”

event_chronicle.description: Véra interrupts the romantic pairings of Nicholas/Sónya and Borís/Natásha, causing a scene and driving them away.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: All four, like a flock of scared birds, got up and left the room.

event_chronicle.description: Anna Mikháylovna and the Countess discuss the Rostóvs' declining financial situation due to the Count's extravagance.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “Don’t I know that at the rate we are living our means won’t last long? It’s all the Club and his easygoing nature.”

event_chronicle.description: Anna Mikháylovna and Borís arrive at the Bezúkhov house to visit the dying Count Cyril.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: Countess Rostóva’s carriage in which they were seated drove over the straw covered street and turned into the wide courtyard of Count Cyril Vladímirovich Bezúkhov’s house.

event_chronicle.description: The doctor Lorrain indicates that Count Bezúkhov's death is certain.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “Prince, humanum est errare, * but...” replied the doctor, swallowing his r’s

event_chronicle.description: Prince Vasíli expresses contempt for Count Ilyá Rostóv.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “I never could understand how Nataly made up her mind to marry that unlicked bear! A perfectly absurd and stupid fellow, and a gambler too, I am told.”

event_chronicle.description: Pierre arrives at his father's house in Moscow and is shunned by his cousins.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: Pierre was received as if he were a corpse or a leper.

event_chronicle.description: Prince Vasíli arrives in Moscow and forbids Pierre from seeing the dying Count.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: The count is very, very ill, and you must not see him at all.

event_chronicle.description: Borís visits Pierre and invites him to dinner at the Rostóvs'.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: Count Rostóv asks you to come to dinner today.

event_chronicle.description: Countess Rostóva requests and receives 700 rubles from Count Rostóv to assist Anna Mikháylovna.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “Bring me...” he reflected a moment, “yes, bring me seven hundred rubles, yes! But mind, don’t bring me such tattered and dirty notes as last time, but nice clean ones for the countess.”

event_chronicle.description: The Countess gives the money to Anna Mikháylovna for Borís's military equipment.
event_chronicle.evidence_quote: “This is for Borís from me, for his outfit.” Anna Mikháylovna was already embracing her and weeping.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER I
chapter_summaries.summary: In July 1805, Anna Pávlovna Schérer, a maid of honor to the Empress, hosts a reception in St. Petersburg. She greets Prince Vasíli Kurágin with a passionate political tirade against Napoleon (Buonaparte) and the state of European politics. They discuss the impending war, the role of Emperor Alexander, and the arrival of guests including the Vicomte de Mortemart and Abbé Morio.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER II
chapter_summaries.summary: Anna Pávlovna’s reception continues as more members of Petersburg high society arrive, including Prince Vasíli’s children, Hélène and Hippolyte, and the pregnant Princess Bolkónskaya. The social atmosphere is defined by rigid etiquette, specifically the mandatory greeting of Anna's aunt. Pierre Bezúkhov, the illegitimate son of a dying grandee, makes a socially awkward entrance, causing anxiety for the hostess due to his lack of conformity to courtly manners.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER III
chapter_summaries.summary: Anna Pávlovna organizes her guests into three distinct groups to facilitate conversation. The primary focus is on the Vicomte de Mortemart, whom Anna 'serves up' as a storyteller to discuss the murder of the Duc d’Enghien. Hélène Kurágina and Lise Bolkónskaya join this circle, while Prince Hippolyte Kurágin is introduced as Hélène's physically similar but intellectually inferior brother.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER IV
chapter_summaries.summary: Prince Andrew Bolkónski arrives at the soirée, displaying a weary and bored demeanor toward high society and his wife, Lise. He reveals he is departing for war as an aide-de-camp to General Kutúzov. Pierre Bezúkhov shows great affection for Andrew, and they agree to meet for supper. Meanwhile, Prince Vasíli and Hélène depart, but not before Princess Drubetskáya entreats Vasíli to use his influence to secure a military appointment for her son, Borís.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER V
chapter_summaries.summary: The conversation at Anna Pávlovna's soirée turns to Napoleon's recent actions in Italy and the execution of the Duc d’Enghien. Pierre Bezúkhov shocks the aristocratic guests by defending Napoleon's actions as political necessities for the general good, while Prince Andrew supports Pierre's logic despite his own cynical outlook. The hostess, Anna Pávlovna, attempts to steer the conversation away from Pierre's controversial and socially inappropriate defense of the Revolution.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER VI
chapter_summaries.summary: As the soiree concludes, Pierre's social awkwardness is highlighted, though Anna Pávlovna offers him a mild, conditional forgiveness. Prince Hippolyte flirtatiously attends to Princess Lise, much to the indifference of Prince Andrew. Anna Pávlovna and Lise finalize a plan to match Anatole Kurágin with Andrew's sister. The chapter ends with Pierre and Andrew arriving at Andrew's home, where they begin a private discussion about Pierre's future and the political ideas discussed at the party.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER VII
chapter_summaries.summary: Prince Andrew, Pierre, and Princess Lise Bolkónskaya converse in Andrew's study. Lise expresses her fear and resentment regarding Andrew's departure for the war, accusing him of being an egotist and changing toward her. The interaction reveals a deep marital strain, with Andrew treating her with cold, formal politeness while Pierre watches with awkward discomfort. The chapter ends with Lise's emotional outburst subsiding into a piteous submission before she retires for the night.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER VIII
chapter_summaries.summary: Prince Andrew and Pierre have a private supper where Andrew reveals his deep disillusionment with marriage and high society. He warns Pierre never to marry, describing his own life as 'spoiled' and his wife as a burden to his freedom. Pierre, in turn, expresses his admiration for Andrew's strength of character and confesses his own uncertainty about his future as an illegitimate son.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER IX
chapter_summaries.summary: Pierre, despite his promise to Prince Andrew, attends a rowdy gathering at Anatole Kurágin's house. The party features heavy drinking and a dangerous bet involving Dólokhov drinking a bottle of rum on a window ledge. Pierre demonstrates his physical strength by wrenching out a window frame to facilitate the stunt.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER X
chapter_summaries.summary: Prince Vasíli fulfills his promise to Princess Drubetskáya, securing Borís a transfer to the Guards. Anna Mikháylovna and Borís travel to Moscow to stay with their wealthy relatives, the Rostóvs. The chapter introduces the Rostóv household during a name-day celebration for the mother and youngest daughter, both named Nataly. The social atmosphere is busy with visitors discussing the failing health of Count Bezúkhov and the scandalous behavior of his son Pierre in Petersburg.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XI
chapter_summaries.summary: The formal atmosphere of the Rostóv drawing room is interrupted by the exuberant entrance of the younger generation, including Natásha, Nicholas, Sónya, and Pétya. Natásha, celebrating her name day, displays her childish charm and laughter, while the dynamics between the young adults—particularly Borís and Nicholas—are established through their contrasting social ease and physical descriptions.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XII
chapter_summaries.summary: The drawing room conversation continues with a focus on Nicholas Rostóv's decision to join the army. Nicholas expresses his passion for military service, while Sónya's romantic devotion to him is highlighted. A flirtatious interaction between Nicholas and Julie Karágina causes Sónya to leave the room in distress, prompting Nicholas to follow her. The elders, including the Count and Countess, discuss the upbringing of their children and Natásha's musical talent.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XIII
chapter_summaries.summary: In the conservatory of the Rostóv house, Natásha hides and observes a tender reconciliation between Nicholas and Sónya, who reaffirm their love with a kiss. After they leave, Natásha lures Borís to her hiding spot, where she impulsively kisses him and secures a promise that he will ask for her hand in marriage in four years when she is sixteen.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XIV
chapter_summaries.summary: Countess Rostóva and Princess Anna Mikháylovna have a private conversation about their financial struggles and social maneuvering. Meanwhile, the eldest daughter Véra interrupts the younger couples—Nicholas and Sónya, and Borís and Natásha—causing friction with her cold and critical demeanor. Anna Mikháylovna reveals how she used Prince Vasíli's influence to secure Borís's commission.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XV
chapter_summaries.summary: Princess Anna Mikháylovna and her son Borís visit the dying Count Cyril Bezúkhov in Moscow. While Borís feels humiliated by their poverty and his mother's sycophancy, Anna Mikháylovna persists in seeking favor from Prince Vasíli, who is managing the Count's affairs. They meet Prince Vasíli as he is dismissing the doctor, Lorrain, and Anna Mikháylovna attempts to secure her son's future by reminding the Prince of his obligations and the Count's role as Borís's godfather.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XVI
chapter_summaries.summary: Pierre Bezúkhov arrives in Moscow after being expelled from Petersburg for his scandalous behavior. He is coldly received by his cousins, the princesses, at his dying father's house. Prince Vasíli arrives and forbids Pierre from seeing the count. Later, Borís Drubetskóy visits Pierre to invite him to dinner at the Rostóvs', leading to a conversation where Pierre's social clumsiness and political obsessions are contrasted with Borís's cool, observant nature.

chapter_summaries.title: CHAPTER XVII
chapter_summaries.summary: Countess Rostóva, moved by Anna Mikháylovna's poverty, asks her husband for money. Despite their own financial decline, Count Rostóv provides seven hundred rubles. When Anna Mikháylovna returns from visiting the dying Count Bezúkhov, the Countess gives her the money for Borís's military outfit, leading to a tearful and affectionate exchange between the two lifelong friends.
